timeline.bodyText: If you are going to be catching a ClassCastException you might as well forego the instanceof check.
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: It doesn't disturb maintainability of the code (so it's not much extra boilerplate code) and I think in terms of performance it's a bit cheaper then the ClassCastException. Nevertheless, I have no trong opinion on this.
replies.author: pfink

replies.bodyText: The ideal solution would involve generics to discern the type for a EirRecord, but I think that makes things a bit more complicated than is necessary. At the very least, make the try/catch block as small as possible so it is easy to understand the cast that is "expected" to go wrong.
replies.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText: I agree with generics, but I also agree it would exceed the scope of this PR.
replies.author: pfink

replies.bodyText: I decided for removing the instanceof check to not further segregate the code.
replies.author: pfink

timeline.bodyText: why are you getting rid of these? Aren't these checks important?
timeline.author: cpmeister

replies.bodyText:
As mentioned in the first PR:
I removed waiting for a SCAN_RESPONSE, as not all devices do send a scan response at all (e.g. EnOcean PTM215B) which completely blocks discovery.  I don't really know for which use case it was added, so I'm not sure what would be a better implementation. I think Bluez has no such thing (because Bluez discovery also works for devices that don't send a scan response).
More detailed thoughts on this:
If you have an idea how to follow the original intention of these checks while getting devices that don't send a scan response discovered as well, I'm open to it. Unfortunately, I only have "fire&forget" BLE devices who all do not send a scan response.
I'm not saying it's the best option to remove it, but for now afaik we have not a single binding that makes use of scan response data, all of them check discovery upon manufacturerId or (short) device name which is based on advertisement, not on scan response. Anyhow, we have a binding in the pipe which does not send scan responses and does not work with this check.
So by removing it, everything that currently exists will still work, and bindings in the pipe which don't send a scan response will additionally work.
I'm not sure if there will be a big need to have the scan response before discovery in the near future, but if yes, it'll probably be more a convienience functionality than something which is required for the discovery to properly work. If there is such use case, I think this can still be (re-)implemented in a better way so it'll work for all devices.
Personally, I don't want to come up with an ideal implementation without having a possibility to test this implementation properly with a real device using it. So for now, I'd like to continue with this unpretentious implementation which works better than the current one for all existing and upcoming bindings.
We can also put it in comments so that future people who need a scan response can build up on the past (not working) code base and this discussion.
replies.author: pfink

replies.bodyText: Well you convinced me. Just get rid of the scanResponses field too since that now serves no purpose.
replies.author: cpmeister

timeline.bodyText: I wouldn't remove this just yet. Discovery needs to be reworked here and I think some of that work is happening in PR #6921 . There is no harm in leaving this in for now.
